shloka_sanskrit:
शुक्लाम्बरधरं विष्णुं शशिवर्णं चतुर्भुजम् ।
प्रसन्नवदनं ध्यायेत् सर्वविघ्नोपशान्तये ॥
transliteration:
Śuklāmbaradharaṁ Viṣṇuṁ Śaśivarṇaṁ Caturbhujam.
Prasannavadanaṁ Dhyāyet Sarvavighnopasāntaye.
purpose: This shloka is traditionally recited at the very beginning of prayers, rituals, or important tasks. It invokes Lord Ganesha in his form as the one clad in white, with a serene, moon-like radiance, and a pleasant face. By meditating upon this form, devotees believe that the environment is purified, the mind is calmed, and all obstacles are removed, creating a sacred and harmonious start to any celebration or endeavor.

shloka_sanskrit:
ॐ एकदन्ताय विद्महे,
वक्रतुंडाय धीमहि,
तन्नो दन्ति प्रचोदयात् ॥
transliteration:
Aum Ekadantaya Viddhamahe,
Vakratundaya Dhimahi,
Tanno Danti Prachodayat.
purpose: Known as the Ganesha Gayatri Mantra, this prayer seeks intellectual clarity and wisdom. By invoking Lord Ganesha as Ekadanta (the one-tusked) and Vakratunda (the curved-trunked), the devotee asks for mental strength, focus, and spiritual insight. Reciting this mantra is believed to sharpen intellect, dispel ignorance, and provide guidance in learning, making it especially meaningful for students and seekers of knowledge.

shloka_sanskrit:
वक्रतुण्ड महाकाय सूर्यकोटि समप्रभ।
निर्विघ्नं कुरु मे देव सर्वकार्येषु सर्वदा॥
transliteration:
Vakratuṇḍa Mahākāya Sūryakoṭi Samaprabha.
Nirvighnaṁ Kuru Me Deva Sarvakāryeṣu Sarvadā.
purpose: This is one of the most widely recited Ganesha shlokas. It describes Him as having a large form, a curved trunk, and brilliance equal to millions of suns. The prayer directly appeals to Ganesha to remove all obstacles and difficulties in every task, at all times. Devotees chant this before starting important ventures, journeys, or ceremonies, trusting in Ganesha's role as Vighnaharta—the remover of hindrances.

shloka_sanskrit:
गणानां त्वा गणपतिं हवामहे।
कविं कवीनामुपमश्रवस्तमम्।
ज्येष्ठराजं ब्रह्मणां ब्रह्मणस्पत।
आ नः श्रृण्वन्नूतिभिः सीद सादनम् ॥
transliteration:
Gaṇānāṁ Tvā Gaṇapatiṁ Havāmahe.
Kaviṁ Kavīnām Upamaśravastamam.
Jyeṣṭharājaṁ Brahmaṇāṁ Braḥmaṇaspata.
Ā Naḥ Śr̥ṇvannūtibhiḥ Sīda Sādanam.
purpose: This Vedic hymn, taken from the Rig Veda, is one of the oldest known invocations to Lord Ganesha. It acknowledges Him as the leader of all beings (Ganapati), the wisest of the wise, and the one who presides over prayers and sacred knowledge. By chanting this, devotees invite Ganesha into their homes and hearts, requesting His blessings for prosperity, abundance, and the smooth performance of rituals. It reinforces Ganesha's role as the divine authority who grants fortune and stability.

shloka_sanskrit:
अगजानन पद्मार्कं गजाननं अहर्निशम्।
अनेकदन्तं भक्तानां एकदन्तं उपास्महे॥
transliteration:
Agajānana Padmārkaṁ Gajānanaṁ Aharniśam.
Anekadantaṁ Bhaktānāṁ Ekadantaṁ Upāsmahe.
purpose: This chant lovingly recalls Ganesha as the son of Goddess Parvati (Agajanana), comparing his radiant face to the sun. It emphasizes His role as protector and constant companion of devotees. By meditating on Him day and night, devotees seek His compassion, blessings, and guidance. The repetition of His epithets—Anekadanta (many-toothed) and Ekadanta (one-tusked)—highlights His uniqueness and divine mystery. This shloka is often recited for inner strength and reassurance.

shloka_sanskrit:
गजाननं भूतगणादिसेवितम्
कपित्थजम्बूफलसारभक्षितम्।
उमासुतं शोकविनाशकारणम्
नमामि विघ्नेश्वरपादपङ्कजम् ॥
transliteration:
Gajānanam Bhūta Gaṇādisevitam
Kapittha Jambūphala Sārabhakṣitam.
Umāsutaṁ Śokavināśakāraṇam
Namāmi Vighneśvara Pādapaṅkajam.
purpose: This devotional hymn paints a vivid picture of Lord Ganesha: attended by divine beings, enjoying fruits, the beloved son of Goddess Uma (Parvati), and the destroyer of sorrow. It shifts the devotee's approach from asking for favors to offering pure reverence and gratitude. Bowing at His lotus feet symbolizes humility and surrender, while acknowledging Ganesha as the compassionate remover of suffering. This is an ideal chant to express appreciation during the festivities.

shloka_sanskrit:
प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं गौरीपुत्रं विनायकम्।
भक्तावासं स्मरेन्नित्यमायुः कामार्थ सिद्धये॥
transliteration:
Praṇamya Śirasā Devaṁ Gaurīputraṁ Vināyakam.
Bhaktāvāsaṁ Smarennityamāyuḥ Kāmārtha Siddhaye.
purpose: This shloka is recited with devotion and humility, bowing to Lord Vinayaka, the son of Goddess Gauri. It emphasizes remembering Him daily as the eternal refuge of devotees. Chanting this prayer is believed to grant longevity, fulfillment of desires, and success in both material and spiritual pursuits. On the final day of Ganesh Chaturthi, this verse is especially meaningful as it reassures devotees that even after Visarjan, Ganesha remains ever-present in their lives and hearts.
